content.body: My colleague who works with me told me that the heading level cannot be used in the <li> tag, so I wonder if it is correct.

content.body: So only in terms of grammar?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: So only in terms of grammar?

content.body: it *can* be semantically correct if organizing the sections and heading in this way would also make sense *for your content* in a screen reader, automatic table-of-contents generator etc.
content.formatted_body: it can be semantically correct if organizing the sections and heading in this way would also make sense for your content in a screen reader, automatic table-of-contents generator etc.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: it *can* be semantically correct if organizing the sections and heading in this way would also make sense *for your content* in a screen reader, automatic table-of-contents generator etc.
it can be semantically correct if organizing the sections and heading in this way would also make sense for your content in a screen reader, automatic table-of-contents generator etc.

content.body: e.g. if you're using <h3> as a way to affect the style but it doesn't represent an actual heading, then it's not "semantically correct", as that H3 would appear in your table of contents as a heading (as one example)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: e.g. if you're using <h3> as a way to affect the style but it doesn't represent an actual heading, then it's not "semantically correct", as that H3 would appear in your table of contents as a heading (as one example)

content.body: My colleage called it a grammatical error that <h2> or <h3> is contained in <li>. But I didn't think it was an error, and I couldn't detect any errors in the actual validation.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: My colleage called it a grammatical error that <h2> or <h3> is contained in <li>. But I didn't think it was an error, and I couldn't detect any errors in the actual validation.

content.body:
> <@ryushin0:matrix.org> My colleage called it a grammatical error that <h2> or <h3> is contained in <li>. But I didn't think it was an error, and I couldn't detect any errors in the actual validation.

AFAIK it's not a grammatical error and semantical errors are more about the content.
